Method Detail

defaultExtension

public abstract String defaultExtension()
Indicates the standard extension used for the writer's shortcut type.

Returns:
The extension, without a period (e.g. "url", "desktop", "webloc"). Non-null.

write

public abstract void write(OutputStream stream,
                           String name,
                           String url)
                    throws ShortcutWriteException
Similar to write(File, String, String) but writes to a stream instead of a file.

Parameters:
stream - The stream to write to. The stream is automatically closed when finished writing.
name - The name of the shortcut. This may be ignored depending on the shortcut type.
url - The URL.
Throws:
ShortcutWriteException - If any error occurs while writing to the stream.

createFullFilename

public String createFullFilename(String name)
Creates a file name based on the specified shortcut name. The goal is to allow the file to be stored on a wide variety of operating systems without issues (however, there are no guarantees that the file name will work on all operating systems). The following rules are used:
  • An appropriate extension is added based on the shortcut type (e.g. ".url").
  • Removes characters which are prohibited in some file systems (such as "?" and ":"). Note there may still be characters left that will cause difficulty, such as spaces and single quotes.
  • If the resulting name (after removing characters) is an empty string, the file will be named "_".
  • Unicode characters are not changed. If there are unicode characters, they could cause problems on some file systems. If you do not want unicode characters in the file name, you are responsible for removing them or converting them to ASCII.
  • If the filename is longer than the length specified by DEFAULT_MAX_FILENAME_LENGTH (including the extension), it will be truncated. This maximum length was chosen somewhat arbitrarily. You may optionally override it by using createFullFilename(String, int).

Parameters:
name - The name to use as the base of the file name.
Returns:
A valid file name with a complete extension. Non-null.

createBaseFilename

public String createBaseFilename(String name)
Similar to createFullFilename(String), but the extension is not included. The same length rules are followed, and this method returns the same base name as createFullFilename(String)

Parameters:
name - The name to use as the base of the file name.
Returns:
A valid file name without an extension. Non-null.

createFullFilename

public String createFullFilename(String name,
                                 int maxLength)
Creates a file name. See createFullFilename(String) for details.

Parameters:
name - The name to use as the base of the file name.
maxLength - The maximum length of the file name (including the extension). Must be large enough to accommodate the extension plus a one-character base file name.
Returns:
A valid file name with a complete extension. The size will be less than maxLength. Non-null.

createBaseFilename

public String createBaseFilename(String name,
                                 int maxLength)
Similar to createFullFilename(String,int), but the extension is not included. The same length rules are followed, and this method returns the same base name as createFullFilename(String,int)

Parameters:
name - The name to use as the base of the file name.
maxLength - The maximum length of the file name (including the extension). Must be large enough to accommodate the extension plus a one-character base file name.
Returns:
A valid file name without an extension. When an extension (with a period) is added to the returned file name, the resulting string is guaranteed to be less than maxLength. Non-null.

write

public void write(File file,
                  String name,
                  String url)
           throws FileAlreadyExistsException,
                  ShortcutWriteException
Writes a shortcut file. The shortcut will contain the specified name/title and URL. Note that some shortcuts do not contain a name inside the file, in which case the name parameter is ignored. If your URL contains unicode characters, it is recommended that you convert it to an ASCII-only URL (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationalized_domain_name ). That being said, DesktopShortcutWriter and UrlShortcutWriter will write unicode URLs. The webloc writers should as well, although this functionality requires more testing.

Parameters:
file - The file to write to. The file must not already exist.
name - The name of the shortcut. These may be ignored depending on the shortcut type.
url - The URL.
Throws:
FileAlreadyExistsException
ShortcutWriteException - If any error occurs while writing the file.
